author: sky.cactus
content: I may not be following fully, but I don't think there is a strong need for being able to diff any two arbitrary forks.  There is only a need to be able to diff two adjascent forks.

author: sky.cactus
content:
One can imagine authoring and maintaining a spec document using traditional GitHub pull requests/branching/etc. for things like formatting changes, clarification, refactoring, etc.

Separately you can have a system for managing forks such that the entire fork is merged at once, and immediately prior to merging the fork you ensure that the formatting/refactoring is in sync between the two.

author: sky.cactus
content: So you have some `London` branch and a `Berlin` branch.  You iterate on Berlin and are constantly rebasing `London` onto `Berlin`, so you are pulling in any formatting/refactoring changes.  Once `London` launches, `Berlin` becomes frozen and `London` becomes the new `main`.

author: sky.cactus
content: You now will forever have a very clean diff between `Berlin` and `London`, and you can continue iterating on the formatting/style/refactoring of `main/London` branch until it becomes frozen with `Shanghai`.

author: sky.cactus
content: As long as you only apply refactoring/formatting/etc. to the current `main` branch, you don't have to worry about adjascent fork diffs becoming hard to read.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't *think* anyone is arguing that we need to be able to create a clean diff between `Homestead` and `London` (though if someone is, I am curious about the use case).

author: samwilsn
content:
> `Berlin` becomes frozen

The problem is that `Berlin` never actually becomes frozen, since the specification is a living document. Even if we manage to perfectly specify a hardfork without bugs or inaccuracies, there's always the chance that a retroactive-but-compatible rule change gets implemented, and we need to update the specs.

> I don't think there is a strong need for being able to diff any two arbitrary forks

I don't think anyone was asking for that, but if I gave that impression, it's my bad. `A` and `B` in my above examples are always adjacent forks.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm a little dubious about the need to be able to retroactively update fork specifications.

author: sky.cactus
content: Or more specifically, the value being able to do so adds compared to the cost of being able to do so (*way* more complexity in specification maintenance).

author: sky.cactus
content: I can certainly come up with contrived reasons one may want to do that, and even some not so contrived ones.  However, none of them outweigh the maintenance complexity cost of being able to actually make such changes to the spec.

author: samwilsn
content:
I really don't think it's going to be that much of an issue. I honestly think it'll be pretty easy, even without tooling.

I just want `diff -U1 src/ethereum/frontier src/ethereum/homestead` to produce some mostly readable output.

author: samwilsn
content: (or `git diff .....` if we end up using branches to organize forks)

author: samwilsn
content:
This might be a pipe dream, but the tools _seem_ to exist to make a pretty-printed diff:

 - https://github.com/sphinx-contrib/restbuilder - renders documentation back into reStructuredText
 - https://github.com/live-clones/docutils/tree/master/sandbox/rstdiff - diffs two reStructuredText documents, into multiple formats

I doubt it'd work out of the box, but could be worth a try?

author: ssh4098
content: I've been dreaming of having a nice, interactive ui for displaying specifications and integrating their evolution (and ideally other metadata/discussions)

author: potuz
content: There's benefit in being able to diff separate forks. Often times different set of features are being worked separately. Currently there are implementations of Altair, the merge and now/soon sharding, all on top of phase 0. Even after Altair goes live, it's not inconceivable that client developers would want to have diffs to phase0 any way since their structures may not be delivered classes from Altair. In any case, maintaining diffs among arbitrary forks seems impossible, I just wanted to point out that the way currently the eth2 spec works, showing diffs of three different forks, all based on phase0, is useful
